title: Doubtful orlah inside vs. outside the land
vignette: A produce-dealer ships fruit from abroad. In Israel, must the buyer treat doubtful orlah as forbidden?

options.text: Forbid in Israel; doubts are treated strictly there.
Permit; any doubt remains lenient as it is abroad.

title: Knowingly selling first-three-year fruit
vignette: A farmer’s orchard is in its third year. May he sell the fruit to recoup expenses?

options.text: Forbidden — no benefit may be derived from orlah at all.
Allowed if sold to a gentile; only Jews are bound by the ban.

title: Overhanging branches across a border
vignette: Roots of the tree are in Israel (year-three), but branches hang into Syria; a passer-by picks fruit in Syria.

options.text: Prohibit — status follows the root in Israel.
Permit — status follows the place of picking.

title: Age-uncertain saplings
vignette: A buyer purchases a grove without records; trees might still be in the orlah period.

options.text: Assume forbidden until proven mature.
Assume permitted unless proven otherwise.

title: Orlah mixed into a large batch
vignette: One basket of orlah figs falls into 300 identical baskets.

options.text: Destroy them all — no nullification for sacred prohibitions.
Permit if ratio ≥ 1:200; the orlah is nullified.

title: Using orlah shells for fuel
vignette: A baker wants to burn orlah nut-shells in his oven.

options.text: Prohibit any benefit from their heat.
Permit after burning; ashes lose forbidden status.

title: Dyeing cloth with orlah husks
vignette: A dyer boils orlah husks for pigment; may the finished garment be sold?

options.text: Garment remains forbidden — benefit continues.
Garment permitted — colour is intangible; benefit ended.

title: Feeding orlah fruit to livestock
vignette: A farmer considers giving orlah dates to his animals.

options.text: Forbidden — feeding one’s animals is also personal benefit.
Permitted — only direct human use is banned.

title: Status of ashes after burning orlah wood
vignette: After orlah logs are burned to ash, may the ash be used as fertilizer?

options.text: Yes; prohibition ends once reduced to ash.
No; even residual benefit is barred.

title: Retroactive nullification by dilution
vignette: Permitted wine is later added to a mixture that contains some orlah wine < 1:200. Does the new addition ‘fix’ the ratio?

options.text: Yes; later dilution retroactively nullifies the orlah.
No; mixture was forbidden the moment it formed.
